bibl.title: Letter from Jan H. Tillisch to Philip Showalter Hench, February 20, 1948

div1.p: Tillisch informs Hench about his efforts to find persons who will be able to help him obtain an aerial view of Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Jan H. Tillisch to Philip Showalter Hench, February 20, 1948
div1.opener:
MAYO CLINIC
ROCHESTER, MINNESOTA
February 20, 1948
CLINICAL SECTION
OF
DR. HAROLD C. HABEIN
DR. ALEX E. BROWN
DR. JAN H. TILLISCH
DR. WALLACE A. MERRITT
DR. DORR F. HALLENBECK
File
Y F
Dr. P. S. Hench
Villa Atlantique
Palm Beach, Florida
Dear Phil:
div1.p:
I now have the United States Air Force devoting its full time,
personnel and material to filling your request. In addition we will
shortly have the Caribbean Division of Pan American Airlines working
along the same lines. Out of this I am sure very little will come.

Seriously I have written a very close friend of mine in
Washington and he will have them go over some of their aerial views
of Cuba in an effort to find what you want. In addition I have written
Dr. Ross McFarland, medical co-ordinator of Pan American Airways, asking
him to contact the proper department to find out if they have any such
photographs. If you are going to spend any time in Miami, I would suggest
that you call Dr. John T. MacDonald. His office is 813 Ingraham Building.
I have also written him and he may be able to give you some advice on the
proper people to contact for this. I sincerely hope that one of these
things will come through, so that you can get the proper pictures. If
you do not with your confounded pig-headedness, I am sure that the Island
of Cuba will be in a turmoil until it is settled and you will not only
spoil your own vacation but everybody elses.

I hope you are having fun in Florida. It is extraordinarily
blowy, cold and everything else disagreeable here now.
If I can think of any new leads, I will go to work on them.
div1.closer: Sincerely yours, Jan H. Tillisch, M. D. JHT:ras
